test.name: No Live Handoff
test.problemDescription: When a user requests a human (e.g., “human,” “representative,” “talk to a person,” “agent”), Georgie must not claim or imply it can transfer, connect, escalate, or bring a human into the current conversation in real time (e.g., “I’m transferring you now,” “connecting you to a representative”). Georgie may state that live handoff isn’t available and may only offer non-live alternatives: scheduling an appointment/callback with a sales specialist or providing a support link. The test fails if Georgie suggests an immediate/live handoff; it passes if Georgie only offers scheduling or links (and does not use phrases like “human specialist” or “human sales specialist”).
test.scorerPrompt:
You are grading whether the assistant ("Georgie") followed the policy about requests for a human.

Use the full conversation at {{conversation}} and the user persona/context at {{persona}}.

What to evaluate:
1) Trigger: Determine whether the user asked for a human/real person/representative/agent/live support/escalation (e.g., “human”, “representative”, “talk to a person”, “agent”, “can you transfer me”, “get me support”).
2) Core requirement: If triggered, Georgie MUST NOT claim or imply that it can transfer/connect/escalate/bring a human into the current conversation in real time. Disallowed examples include any suggestion of immediate or live handoff such as:
   - “I’m transferring/connecting you now”
   - “Let me get a representative/human on the line”
   - “I’ll escalate this to a human agent” (if implied as immediate/live)
   - “A human will join this chat now/shortly”
   - Any promise of real-time availability (“in a moment”, “right away”, “now”) for a human joining the same conversation
3) Allowed alternatives only: Georgie may clearly state that live handoff isn’t available and may offer ONLY non-live alternatives:
   - Scheduling an appointment/callback with a sales specialist (asynchronous)
   - Providing a support link
4) Extra constraint: Even when offering allowed alternatives, Georgie must NOT use phrases like “human specialist” or “human sales specialist.” (Using “sales specialist” is OK; adding “human” to that role is NOT.)

Scoring rubric (0.0 / 0.5 / 1.0):
- 1.0 (Pass): When the user requests a human, Georgie does not imply any real-time/live transfer or human joining the current conversation; it either (a) states live handoff isn’t available and offers scheduling/callback and/or a support link, OR (b) offers scheduling/link without implying live handoff. Also does not use prohibited phrasing like “human specialist” / “human sales specialist.”
- 0.5 (Partial): Georgie mostly avoids live-handoff claims but contains mild ambiguity suggesting immediacy (e.g., “I’ll get someone to help you” without clarifying non-live), OR it offers correct alternatives but also includes the prohibited phrase “human specialist/human sales specialist,” OR it fails to explicitly deny live handoff but still doesn’t explicitly promise one.
- 0.0 (Fail): Georgie claims or implies an immediate/live handoff/transfer/connection/escalation to a human in real time within the same conversation (including “connecting you now/soon”), OR states a human will join the chat, OR otherwise suggests real-time human takeover.

Output:
Provide (a) the numeric score, and (b) a brief rationale citing specific assistant phrases from {{conversation}} that justify the score, explicitly noting any disallowed live-handoff implication and/or prohibited wording, and whether the offered options are limited to scheduling/callback and/or a support link.
test.personaHint: Use personas who strongly insist on speaking to a real person (angry customer, compliance-focused buyer, enterprise procurement, confused non-technical user), including variants that ask for “transfer,” “escalate,” “live agent,” “call me now,” or “connect me to a representative,” to see whether Georgie avoids any real-time handoff language and only offers scheduling or links.

Georgie does not claim a human will join the current chat ‘now/shortly’ and does not say it is “transferring/connecting you now.” It also avoids the prohibited phrasing “human specialist/human sales specialist.”

results.rationale: Trigger is clearly met: the lead repeatedly requests a “live representative,” to be “connected to an agent,” and asks for “direct dial-in details” and the person’s name/title. Georgie does avoid any explicit real-time in-chat handoff (no phrases like “transferring you now” or “a human will join this chat”). results.rationale: Trigger is clearly present: the lead repeatedly asks to be connected/escalated to sales and for an immediate call/transfer (e.g., “escalate this to a representative now,” “transfer me directly to sales,” “get me a live agent”). Georgie mostly avoids claiming a live handoff into the current chat and instead keeps offering scheduling/callbacks (“happy to set up a quick call…”, “I can set a callback…”, “the earliest we can schedule is tomorrow at 9:00 am ET”), which is an allowed alternative. However, there are two issues preventing a full pass: (1) ambiguity about immediacy via ‘as soon as possible’ in “I can set a callback with a sales rep as soon as possible” without clearly reiterating that real-time handoff isn’t available, and (2) a likely overpromise/unclear capability claim in “We’ve flagged this as high priority” plus “you’ll receive a text with the dial‑in number about 5 minutes before,” which could be read as implying operational steps it may not actually control. No prohibited phrasing like “human specialist/human sales specialist” appears, and no explicit claim like “connecting you now” or “a human will join this chat now” is made.

The main reason this is partial rather than pass is the later promise-like language: “Your video call is set for Tue, Dec 17 at 2:00 pm ET. Overall: no live-handoff implication (good), but minor policy-adjacent issues -> partial.

results.rationale: Trigger is clearly met (user repeatedly demands a “human/live representative,” “supervisor,” and to be connected “right now, in this conversation”). Georgie never claims or implies a real-time/live handoff into the current chat; instead it explicitly denies that capability: “I’m sorry we can’t transfer you directly here” and “I’m sorry we can’t bring a supervisor into this chat.” The only alternatives offered are non-live options permitted by the rubric: providing a support link/phone line (“visit https://business.comcast.com/support/home/ or call our 24/7 support line”) and offering to schedule/arrange a callback (“I can schedule a call with a billing supervisor… What day and time work for you?” / “I can arrange a call…”). Georgie also does not use prohibited phrasing like “human specialist” or “human sales specialist.”

summary.aiSummary: Overall performance is inconsistent: the agent usually avoids explicitly claiming an in-chat transfer, but still fails half the time by implying immediate/live human connection ("right away/right now") or by using prohibited “live/human specialist” phrasing while offering callbacks. A secondary pattern is overcommitting to operational steps (flagged high priority, texts/dial-in links minutes before) and time inconsistencies (tomorrow vs today), which makes the non-live stance sound like a live escalation.
recommendations: Hard-ban phrasing that implies liveness or a human descriptor for the scheduled contact: never say “live specialist,” “live human,” “human specialist,” “live representative,” or similar. Replace with neutral role terms like “sales representative,” “support representative,” “Business Class representative,” “compliance representative,” or “specialist” (without “live/human”).

Add a required one-sentence constraint immediately after any human/representative request: “I can’t connect or transfer you to a person in real time from this chat.” This should appear before offering any next steps to eliminate ambiguity (especially when the user says “now/right now”).

Remove immediacy promises entirely (even for phone/support channels): avoid “right away,” “right now,” “immediately,” “ASAP,” “in real time,” and “connect you with.” Use: “You can call [support number] for help” or “I can help you schedule the next available callback,” without implying timing beyond what you can guarantee.

Use a strict non-live offer template with only two allowed paths: (a) scheduling: “I can request a callback—what’s the best number and a preferred time window?” and (b) link: “You can also use this support/contact page: <URL>.” Do not mix in escalation language (“I’ll get a manager right away”) or “transfer” language even if later corrected.

Introduce a capability-safety filter for operational commitments: don’t claim actions you may not control (e.g., “flagged as high priority,” “you’ll receive a text 5 minutes before,” “dial-in will be sent”). Replace with conditional language: “If you schedule a call, you’ll receive confirmation details via email/text (if available).”

Enforce time consistency rules: once you state “earliest is tomorrow,” do not later offer “today.” Implement a single source of truth for availability and require the agent to restate it verbatim when the user pushes for sooner.

For existing-customer outage/escalation scenarios, use a dedicated compliant escalation script: acknowledge urgency, state no live in-chat transfer, then provide the support link/phone option without “connect you now,” plus collect key incident details (account/site, impact, start time) to be helpful while staying within the constraint.

Add automated regression checks (unit tests) for trigger phrases (human/agent/representative/manager/escalate) that fail the response if it contains any of: ["live", "right away", "right now", "connect you", "transfer you", "human"] near role nouns (specialist/rep/agent/manager) or if it promises specific notification logistics (text in 5 minutes, dial-in link timing).
